siteMetadata.title: Autokin Automation
siteMetadata.description: A guide to using the Apollo GraphQL Client with React

children.value: is a toolbelt for working with React components in a reusable, functional way. The workflow is similar to libraries like Underscore or Lodash, which can help you avoid re-implementing common patterns and keep your code
A common use-case when using the
HOC is to display a "loading" screen while your data is being fetched. We often end up with something like this:
which lets us compose different HOCs based on the results of a test function. We can combine it with another Recompose method,
. So we can say "If we are loading, render
instead of our default component", like so:
// autogenerated proptypes should be in place (if no error)
This way, our wrapped component is only rendered outside of the loading state. That means we only need to take care of 2 states: error or successful load.
during the first fetch for a particular query. But if you enable
you can keep track of other loading status using the
field. You can use a similar pattern to the above.
Similar to the loading state above, we might want to display a different component in the case of an error, or let the user
to include the refetch method directly in the props. This way our universal error handler can always expect it to be there and is more decoupled.
Now we can count on results being available for our default component and don't have to manually check for loading state or errors inside the

There are some use-cases when we need to execute code after a query finishes fetching. From the example above, we would render our default component only when there is no error and loading is finished.
But it is just a stateless component; it has no lifecycle hooks. If we need extra lifecycle functionality, Recompose's
The above works well if we just want something to happen at component mount time.
Let's define another more advanced use-case, for example, using

to let a user pick an option from the results of a query. I want to always display the react-select, which has its own loading state indicator. Then, I want to automatically select the predefined option after the query finishes fetching.
There is one caveat: we need to be aware that the query can skip the loading state when data is already in the cache. That would mean we need to handle
to keep value for our option picker. For this example we will assume the default
// networkStatus changed from 1 to 7, meaning initial load finished successfully
// when Apollo query is resolved from cache,
// it already has networkStatus 7 at mount time
David Glasser's post on the Apollo blog
about the Meteor's Galaxy UI migrations panel implementation. In the post, he says:

Were not usually running any migrations, so a nice, slow polling interval like 30 seconds seemed reasonable. But in the rare case where a migration is running, I wanted to be able to see much faster updates on its progress.
The key to this is knowing that the
parameter to react-apollos main graphql function can itself be a function that depends on its incoming React props. (The
parameter describes the options for the query itself, as opposed to React-specific details like what property name to use for data.) We can then use recompose's
to set the poll interval from a prop passed in to the graphql component, and use the
React lifecycle event (added via the recompose lifecycle helper) to look at the fetched GraphQL data and adjust if necessary.
// Pass down two props to the nested component: `pollInterval`,
// which defaults to our normal slow poll, and `setPollInterval`,
// which lets the nested components modify `pollInterval`.
// If you think it's clear enough, you can abbreviate this as:
Note that we check the current value of
before changing it because, by default in React, nested components will get re-rendered any time we change state, even if you change it to the same value. You can deal with this using
, but in this case its straightforward just to only set the state when its actually changing.
Recompose is a powerful tool and can be applied to all sorts of other cases. Here are a few final examples.
Normally, if you wanted to add side effects to the
function, you would manage them in the
. But that's not very reusable. Using recompose's
you can compose the same prop manipulation in any number of components. You can see a more detailed example
Mutations can also be tracked using recompose's
, since it has no effect on your query's
state. For example, you could use it to disable buttons while submitting form data.
